questions.question:
Question 1: A neonate presented with features of intestinal obstruction. The X-ray showed the following 
image. What is the probable diagnosis?
questions.explanation:
The above plain abdominal radiograph shows a typical double-bubble sign suggestive of duodenal 
atresia. The double-bubble represents dilatation of the stomach and the proximal duodenum. Duodenal atresia is often associated with trisomy 21/Down syndrome, prematurity, maternal 
polyhydramnios, cardiac malformations, and malformations of the hepatobiliary system. It is caused due to failure of recanalization or partial recanalization of the duodenum or failure of 
vacuolization of the duodenum from its solid cord stage. The anatomic variants are as follows: • Type I: • most common • mucosal web with intact muscle wall (so-called windsock deformity) • Type II: • two ends separated by a fibrous cord, but muscle continuity present • Type III: • complete separation of two ends with a gap within the duodenum Clinical features: • Obstructive features such as • bilious emesis (due to duodenal obstruction distal to the ampulla of Vater) 425 
Sold by @itachibot • postprandial emesis • upper abdominal distension with a scaphoid lower abdomen • Delayed passage of meconium Abdominal radiographs show the double-bubble sign. If distal air is present, an upper GI contrast 
study should be considered to exclude midgut volvulus. Treatment: • The initial treatment of infants with duodenal atresia includes nasogastric or orogastric 
decompression. • IV fluids and parenteral nutrition are started to prevent acid-base imbalance. • Echocardiography, renal ultrasound, and radiology of the chest and spine should be performed 
to evaluate for associated anomalies. • Definitive correction of the atresia is done by duodenoduodenostomy. This procedure is also 
preferred in cases of the concomitant or isolated annular pancreas.

questions.question:
Question 2: An infant with Edward's syndrome presents with the following radiological finding. Which of 
the following is false about this condition? 414 
Sold by @itachibot

options.b: Mostly presents as vomiting within 1 week
options.c: Erythromycin exposure in the first 2 weeks of life can lead to this condition
options.d: Palpation of the pyloric olive is pathognomonic for this condition

questions.explanation:
The radiographic image showing the presence of an enlarged gastric gas bubble (single bubble) is 
suggestive of congenital hypertrophic pyloric stenosis (CHPS). It most commonly presents with 
non-bilious projectile vomiting between 2-8 weeks of age and is only rarely seen after 13 weeks. Hypertrophy of the circular muscle of the pylorus results in constriction and obstruction of the 
gastric outlet. First-born male infants are at the highest risk. Risk factors for congenital hypertrophic pyloric stenosis: • Turner syndrome • Edwards syndrome 426 
Sold by @itachibot • Erythromycin or azithromycin exposure in the first 2 weeks of life either orally or via mother's 
milk. Palpation of the olive-shaped mass in the epigastrium is considered pathognomonic. USG criteria for diagnosing hypertrophic pyloric stenosis - pyloric muscle thickness of >3-4 mm 
or a pyloric length >15-18 mm in the presence of functional gastric outlet obstruction is 
diagnostic.

questions.question:
Question 3: An abdominal mass in a patient with congenital hypertrophic pyloric stenosis is best seen 
 
.

options.c: During palpation over the left hypochondrium

questions.explanation:
In a child with congenital hypertrophic pyloric stenosis (CHPS), the abdominal mass is best seen 
during test feed in the right upper quadrant. Hypertrophic pyloric stenosis most presents with non-bilious projectile vomiting. It is 
common between 2 and 8 weeks of age. Hypertrophy of the circular muscle of the pylorus results 
in constriction and obstruction of the gastric outlet. Male infants are at a higher risk. Clinically, when the infant is given a test feed, an olive-shaped mass is palpable in the right upper 
quadrant and visible peristalsis is usually observed moving from left to right across the abdomen. Infants with hypertrophic pyloric stenosis develop a characteristic metabolic 
abnormality- hypochloraemic hypokalaemic metabolic alkalosis. Persistent vomiting results in 
loss of hydrochloric acid leading to the development of metabolic alkalosis (due to loss of H+) 
and hypochloremia (due to loss of Cl-). All infants with congenital hypertrophic pyloric stenosis are evaluated with an ultrasound 
(investigation of choice). It confirms the diagnosis in the majority of cases. Management: Rehydration and metabolic correction prior to definitive surgery - Ramstedt's 
pyloromyotomy.

questions.question:
Question 4: A child is diagnosed with congenital hypertrophic pyloric stenosis. Which among the 
following statements is true regarding her condition?
questions.explanation:
Congenital hypertrophic pyloric stenosis (CHPS) most commonly presents with non-bilious 
projectile vomiting. It is common between 2-8 weeks of age. When the infant is given a test feed, visible peristalsis is usually observed moving from left to 
right, followed by projectile vomiting. Infants with hypertrophic pyloric stenosis develop a characteristic metabolic abnormality i.e 
hypokalemic hypochloremic metabolic alkalosis with paradoxical aciduria. Persistent vomiting results in loss of hydrochloric acid leading to the development 
of metabolic alkalosis (due to loss of H+) and hypochloremia (due to loss of Cl-). The kidneys try 
to compensate for alkalosis by secreting Na+ and HCO3-. However, the loss of sodium stimulates 
the secretion of aldosterone via the RAAS pathway. The aldosterone causes active reabsorption of 
sodium in exchange for K+ and H+ ions. Loss of potassium ions leads to the development 
of hypokalemia. Loss of H+ ions in urine lowers the urinary pH resulting in aciduria. It is 
called paradoxical aciduria, since the body initially lost H+ ions due to loss of HCl, and instead of 427 
Sold by @itachibot compensating that loss, the body is losing more H+ ions through urine. The cervix sign and nipple sign are signs of CHPS seen on ultrasonography: • Double-layered hypertrophic mucosa protrudes into the stomach, creating the so-called nipple 
sign. • The sonographic appearance of the hypertrophied pylorus resembles that of the uterine cervix 
and is sometimes referred to as the cervix sign. The given ultrasound image shows thickened pylorus, with cervix sign and nipple sign. Treatment: • The child should be rehydrated and the metabolic abnormality has to be 
corrected preoperatively. • The Ramstedt pyloromyotomy is the standard surgical procedure for its treatment.

questions.question: Question 5: Which part of the GIT is most sensitive to ischemia following a hypovolemic insult?
questions.explanation:
Tonometry studies have shown that of all the parts of the gastrointestinal tract (GIT), the stomach 
is most sensitive to ischemia following a hypovolemic insult and is also the slowest to recover. This may explain the high incidence of stress ulceration in the stomach. The Griffiths point (or Griffiths critical point) refers to the site of watershed anastomosis between 
the ascending left colic artery and the marginal artery of Drummond occurring in the region of the 
splenic flexure. Most anatomy texts describe its location as two-thirds along the transverse colon. The Sudeck point (or Sudeck critical point) refers to a specific location in the arterial supply of the 
rectosigmoid junction, namely the origin of the last sigmoid arterial branch from the inferior 
mesenteric artery (IMA). 428 
Sold by @itachibot

questions.question: Question 6: What is the most common cause of upper GI bleeding?
questions.explanation: The most common cause of upper GI bleeding is peptic ulcer. The causes of upper GI bleed in decreasing order of frequency: • Ulcers • Esophageal (6%) • Gastric (21%) • Duodenal (33%) • Erosions • Mallory–Weiss tear • Esophageal varices • Tumour • Vascular lesions

questions.question:
Question 7: A 35-year-old man came with complaints of dark-colored stools to the OPD. After undergoing 
endoscopy, the patient was diagnosed with an upper GI bleed. Which of the following 
structures is used as a demarcation point to differentiate it from a lower GI bleed?
questions.explanation:
The ligament of Treitz is used as the demarcation point to differentiate between upper 
gastrointestinal bleeding and lower gastrointestinal bleeding. It is a part of the duodenojejunal 
junction. Upper GI bleeding refers to bleeding proximal to the ligament of Treitz, and lower GI bleeding 
refers to bleeding distal to the ligament of Treitz. 429 
Sold by @itachibot

questions.question:
Question 8: A 45-year-old chronic alcoholic, with a history of binge drinking and multiple episodes of 
vomiting, presents with hematemesis. On endoscopy, a longitudinal mucosal tear is found in 
the gastroesophageal junction. What is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.explanation:
The given clinical scenario is suggestive of Mallory Weiss tear. It is due to a longitudinal tear in 
mucosa or submucosa of the gastroesophageal junction. It is most commonly seen in alcoholics, following forceful vomiting, retching, coughing, or 
straining. The left gastric artery is the most common vessel to bleed. The investigation of choice is 
endoscopy. Management of Mallory Weiss tear • Conservative, as it is usually is self-limiting. • Endoscopic electrocoagulation or sclerosant therapy. • Angiographic embolization - if endoscopy fails. • High gastrotomy - if all these maneuvers fail. Boerhaave syndrome is characterized by spontaneous perforation of the esophagus. Here all layers 
are involved. Clinical features include Mackler's triad • Retching • Chest pain • Subcutaneous emphysema Gastric Antral Vascular Ectasia (GAVE) is characterized by dilated venules in the submucosa of 
the antrum. On endoscopy: Watermelon stomach. 430 
Sold by @itachibot Management of GAVE • Endoscopic argon photocoagulation (APC) • If persistent - antrectomy. Dieulafoy lesion is a vascular malformation (dilated submucosal arterioles) that is seen along the 
lesser curvature of the stomach. The investigation of choice is endoscopy. Management of Dieulafoy lesion: • Endoscopic electrocoagulation or sclerosant therapy • Angiographic embolization.

questions.question:
Question 9: A 25-year-old male patient presented to the OPD with complaints of increasing heartburn and 
dyspepsia for the past several months. He was prescribed PPIs for one month but he has no 
relief. You perform a urea breath test which is found to be positive. What is the most likely 
diagnosis?
questions.explanation:
431 
Sold by @itachibot The given clinical scenario and the positive urea breath test are suggestive of a Helicobacter pylori 
infection which is most commonly associated with Type B gastritis. Type B gastritis usually affects the antrum. Intestinal metaplasia associated with chronic 
pan-gastritis and atrophy is seen. It has greater potential for malignancy as compared to Type A 
gastritis. Type A gastritis affects the fundus with antral sparing. Its features can be easily remembered by 4 
‘A’s: • Autoimmune condition - has circulating antibodies to parietal cells • Atrophy of parietal cell mass • Achlorhydria - causes chronic hypergastrinemia and microadenomas of enterochromaffin-like 
(ECL) cells • Anemia - leads to pernicious anemia, due to malabsorption of Vit B12 (as the intrinsic factor is 
also produced by parietal cells)

questions.question: Question 10: Which of the following causes gastritis in patients with AIDS?
questions.explanation:
Acquired immunodeficiency syndrome (AIDS) gastritis is secondary to infection with 
cryptosporidiosis. Other specific types of gastritis: • Eosinophilic gastritis appears to have an allergic basis and is treated with steroids and 
cromoglycate. • Granulomatous gastritis is seen rarely in Crohn’s disease and also may be associated with 
tuberculosis. • Phlegmonous gastritis is a rare bacterial infection of the stomach, found in patients with severe 
intercurrent illnesses.

questions.question: Question 11: What is the most common site of gastric ulcer?
questions.explanation:
The most common site of gastric ulcer is the lesser curvature near incisura. Approximately 60% of ulcers are in this location and are classified as type I gastric ulcers. These ulcers are generally not associated with excessive acid secretion and may occur with low to 
normal acid output.

questions.question: Question 12: Which type of gastric ulcer has increased gastric acid levels?
questions.explanation:
Gastric ulcers of Types II (gastric body with duodenal ulcer) and III (prepyloric) are associated 
with increased gastric acid levels. 432 
Sold by @itachibot

questions.question:
Question 13: A biopsy was obtained from a patient with chronic peptic ulcer disease. The pathological slide 
is given below. Identify the false statement regarding the causative agent of this condition.

options.b: Causes the most common type of gastritis
options.c: Associated with causation of gastric MALToma
options.d: Considered by WHO as class I carcinogen

questions.explanation:
The given slide shows the GI mucosa, stained with Warthin-Starry silver stain, infected with 
Helicobacter pylori. H. pylori cause hypergastrinemia. The ammonia released by H. pylori acts on the antral G-cells and releases gastrin. This is 
responsible for hypergastrinemia in these patients resulting in type B gastritis (the most common 
type of gastritis). Urea breath test and antibodies to H. pylori help us with diagnosis. The gold standard 
investigation for H. pylori is a tissue biopsy. H. pylori is classified by the WHO as a class I carcinogen because of the production of certain 
cytotoxins, notably the Cag A and Vac A, which are implicated in gastritis, peptic ulceration, and 
cancer.

questions.question:
Question 14: What is the most common complication that you expect in patients suffering from peptic 
ulcer disease?
questions.explanation:
The most common complication of peptic ulcer disease is bleeding, followed by perforation and 
obstruction. The most common site for perforation of peptic ulcers is the first part of the duodenum. Complications of peptic ulcers are • Bleeding - It is the most common complication of posterior duodenal ulcer. • Perforation - It is the most common complication of anterior duodenal ulcer and gastric ulcer. • Obstruction • Hour-glass deformity of the stomach - Large long-standing gastric ulcers can lead to fibrosis. 
fibrosis if present can cause hourglass constriction of the stomach. Barium meal shows double 
pouched stomach. • Tea-pot deformity (handbag stomach) - It is caused by cicatrization and shortening of the lesser 
curvature. • An ulcer can erode posteriorly into the pancreas and anteriorly into the liver. • Malignancy.

questions.question:
Question 15: Which of the following is used for the classification of the endoscopic appearance of bleeding 
peptic ulcers in a patient with peptic ulcer disease?
questions.explanation:
Forrest classification is used for classifying the endoscopic appearance of bleeding peptic ulcers. It 
stratifies the risk of rebleeding based on observed stigmata of recent hemorrhage. Forrest classification is clinically very significant as it provides prognostic information to the 
surgeon about the need for endoscopic therapeutic intervention and the risk of rebleeding. 433 
Sold by @itachibot Option B: The Glasgow–Blatchford bleeding score (GBS) is a screening tool to assess the 
likelihood that a patient with acute upper gastrointestinal bleeding (UGIB) will need medical 
intervention such as a blood transfusion or endoscopic intervention. It incorporates the patient’s 
blood urea level, hemoglobin level, blood pressure, and other clinical parameters. Option C: Rockall score assesses the risk of rebleeding and in-hospital mortality in patients with 
an upper GI bleed. Option D: The Bismuth–Corlette classification system provides an anatomic description of the 
tumor location and longitudinal extension in the biliary tree. Forrest Classification Stigmata of Recent Hemorrh 
age Active Spurting 
I A Active Oozing 
I B Non-bleeding vessel 
II A Adherent Clot 
II B Flat Pigmented Spot 
II C Clean Based Ulcer

questions.question:
Question 16: Which of the following is the most commonly involved vessel in patients with bleeding peptic 
ulcers on the posterior wall?
questions.explanation:
The most common vessel responsible for bleeding in peptic ulcer disease is the gastroduodenal 
artery. Ulcers located in the posterior wall can erode the mucosa and the gastroduodenal artery, 
leading to hematemesis and melena.

questions.question:
Question 17: A 23-year-old woman was admitted to the burns ward with an involvement of 45% of the 
body surface area. She is at an increased risk of developing ulcers in which of the following 
parts of the stomach?
questions.explanation:
434 
Sold by @itachibot A patient with burn is at risk of developing Curling’s ulcers (stress ulcers). Stress ulcers in the 
stomach are located most commonly in the fundus. Stress gastritis occurs after a physical trauma, shock, sepsis, hemorrhage, or respiratory failure. It 
is characterized by multiple superficial (non-ulcerating) erosions that begin in the proximal or 
acid-secreting portion of the stomach and progress distally. They are almost always seen in the 
fundus of the stomach and usually develop within 1 to 2 days after a traumatic event. The stress-induced splanchnic vasoconstriction causes systemic hypotension and reduced blood 
flow leading to mucosal injury. On microscopic examination, they appear as wedge-shaped mucosal hemorrhages, with 
coagulation necrosis of the superficial mucosal cells. Stress ulcers present as painless upper GI 
bleeds. Note: Cushing ulcers arise in individuals with intracranial disease. They occur in the stomach, 
duodenum, and esophagus and carry a high incidence of perforation. They occur due to gastric 
acid hypersecretion from direct vagal nerve stimulation.

questions.question:
Question 18: A 42-year-old man is brought to the emergency room with complaints of severe abdominal 
pain. On examination, his vitals are stable and there is abdominal rigidity and tenderness. 
The erect X-ray of the abdomen is suggestive of pneumoperitoneum and the patient is posted 
for emergency laparotomy. It reveals the presence of a perforated type I gastric ulcer. How 
will you manage this patient? 419 
Sold by @itachibot

options.a: Perform distal gastrectomy with Billroth I anastomosis
options.b: Closure of the perforation with Graham's patch repair

questions.question:
Question 20: A 25-year-old man on SSRI presented with hematemesis and abdominal pain. An endoscopy 
was performed immediately which showed an actively bleeding ulcer of size 2cm in the 
posterior wall of the duodenum. What is the next best step in the management of this 
patient?
questions.explanation:
The next best step to manage the above scenario is endoscopic electrocoagulation. Management of bleeding peptic ulcer For actively bleeding ulcers or non-bleeding visible vessels, • Endoscopic therapy with a combination of epinephrine injection and electrocoagulation is done. 
Surgery is done only when 2 attempts of endoscopic therapy fail. • Surgical management includes duodenostomy and under-running of the vessel. Duodenal ulcers 
also show a good response to acid-reducing surgery or vagotomy. Medical management includes PPIs and H.pylori eradication therapy.

questions.question:
Question 21: Which of the following is the preferred approach for treating a patient who has a duodenal 
ulcer with a perforation of 2.5cm?

options.a: Primary closure and buttress with well-vascularised omentum

questions.explanation:
The preferred treatment of perforations between 1–3 cm in size is a Graham patch repair. 436 
Sold by @itachibot Treatment of perforated duodenal ulcer: • <1 cm: Primary closure + buttress with well-vascularised omentum • 1–3 cm: Graham patch repair • >3 cm: Closure of defect using omentum or jejunal serosa + pyloric exclusion + 
gastrojejunostomy

questions.question:
Question 22: 420 
Sold by @itachibot Which of the following is false about the type of vagotomy shown in the image below?
questions.explanation:
The picture depicts Highly Selective Vagotomy (HSV). Post-procedure acid reduction is minimum 
in HSV. It involves resection of crowfoot branches, 6cm from the gastroesophageal junction but stopped 
7cm from the pylorus. The nerve of Latarjet from the anterior and posterior vagal trunk supplies 
the acid pepsin areas of the stomach. It is spared in HSV. Usually, the motor branch to the 
pylorus is also preserved. There are 3 types of vagotomy • Highly selective vagotomy • Truncal vagotomy + gastrojejunostomy • Truncal vagotomy + antrectomy. Highly selective vagotomy • Acid reduction is minimum. • Highest ulcer recurrence rate. • Minimum postoperative complications. Truncal vagotomy + antrectomy • Acid reduction is maximum. • Least ulcer recurrence rate. • Maximum postoperative complications. Note: Vagal nerves are motor to the stomach and denervation of the antro-pyloro-duodenal 
segment results in gastric stasis after truncal vagotomy. Hence, a drainage procedure, most 
commonly Heineke–Mikulicz pyloroplasty or gastrojejunostomy is done along with vagotomy. The criminal nerve of Grassi is a branch of the posterior vagal trunk that arises at the 
gastroesophageal junction and supplies the fundus of the stomach. It is called a criminal 
nerve because it is often missed during vagotomy procedures and can result in recurrent peptic 
ulcer disease. 437 
Sold by @itachibot

questions.question: Question 23: Identify the surgical procedure shown below.
questions.explanation:
The procedure illustrated in the image is Billroth II gastrectomy. Following resection, the distal 
end of the stomach is narrowed by the closure of the lesser curve aspect of the remnant. The 
greater curve aspect is then anastomosed, usually in a retro-colic fashion, to the jejunum. Option A: In Billroth I gastrectomy, the lower half of the stomach is removed, and the cut end of 
the stomach is anastomosed to the first part of the duodenum. Option C: Braun modification of classical Billroth II gastrectomy is Billroth II reconstruction with 
jejunojejunostomy. Option D: Roux-en Y gastrojejunostomy is a gastric bypass surgery where a loop of jejunum is 
anastomosed to a proximal gastric pouch. 438 
Sold by @itachibot

questions.question:
Question 24: A 40-year-old man presents to the ER with severe abdominal pain. Guarding is present on 
per abdomen examination. HR is 110bpm and BP is 88/60mmHg. Erect abdominal X-ray is 
shown below. Which of the following would you proceed with, for managing this case?
questions.explanation:
The given clinical scenario and erect X-ray abdomen showing gas under the diaphragm 
(pneumoperitoneum) is suggestive of gastrointestinal perforation. It is managed by initial 
resuscitation with IV fluids followed by exploratory laparotomy. It is a surgical emergency. Management includes: • Adequate preoperative resuscitation with intravenous fluids followed by correction of electrolyte 
imbalance, instituting broad-spectrum intravenous antibiotics and • Early surgical intervention/laparotomy to address the cause for pneumoperitoneum and stop 
further contamination of the peritoneal cavity.

questions.question:
Question 25: A 54-year-old man presented with acute onset of abdominal pain, fever, and vomiting. 
Examination revealed tenderness over the right iliac fossa. USG showed gas around the right 
kidney. What is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.explanation:
The given clinical scenario is suggestive of pneumoretroperitoneum caused by a perforated 
duodenal ulcer. Posterior duodenal ulcer perforates into the retroperitoneum, and the contents leak through the 
right paracolic gutter into the right iliac fossa, mimicking appendicitis. This is called Valentino 
syndrome. On USG, gas can be seen around the right kidney known as the renal veil sign.

questions.question:
Question 26: A 30-year-old actress who underwent Roux-en-Y gastric bypass surgery for obesity, presents 
with complaints of sweating, palpitations, epigastric fullness, and loose stools which start 
immediately after meals. Which of the following would you not associate with her condition?

options.a: It is precipitated by carbohydrate rich food.
options.b: It is more common after partial gastrectomy with the Billroth II reconstruction.
options.d: It is relieved by lying down.

questions.explanation:
The clinical scenario is suggestive of early dumping syndrome. Hypoglycemia■ does not occur in 
early dumping syndrome. Hypoglycemia is seen in late dumping syndrome secondary to raised 
insulin levels. Dumping syndrome is a complication occurring post gastrectomy. It can be early or late. Early dumping syndrome is due to the high osmotic load that reaches the small bowel, leading to 
sequestration of fluid from the circulation into the gastrointestinal tract (GIT). This fluid shift 
induces autonomic responses. It is characterized by more GI and fewer cardiovascular effects such 
as: • Epigastric fullness • Sweating • Lightheadedness • Tachycardia • Diarrhea Symptoms are aggravated by having more food and relieved by lying down. 439 
Sold by @itachibot Late dumping syndrome is due to an increase in insulin levels and secondary hypoglycemia. This 
hypoglycemia causes a catecholamine surge, which results in predominantly cardiovascular effects 
such as: • Diaphoresis • Tremulousness • Light-headedness • Tachycardia • Confusion The symptoms are aggravated by exercise and relieved by having food. The principal treatment for both types of dumping syndrome is dietary manipulation. Meals based 
on fat and protein are known to work the best. Octreotide before meals is useful.

questions.question:
Question 27: A patient presented to the casualty with severe upper abdominal pain and recurrent retching 
with minimal vomiting. A nasogastric tube insertion was tried but it was unsuccessful. A chest 
X-ray showed diffuse distension of bowel loops and a left-sided diaphragmatic defect. Which 
of the following statements regarding this condition is false?

options.b: Organoaxial type is associated with a diaphragmatic defect
options.c: Surgery is performed through a transabdominal approach

questions.explanation:
The given clinical scenario is suggestive of gastric volvulus. Organoaxial gastric volvulus is more 
common (66%) than mesenteroaxial volvulus (33%). Organoaxial gastric volvulus: Torsion occurs along the longitudinal axis of the stomach and often 
occurs acutely. It is associated with a diaphragmatic defect. Mesenteroaxial gastric volvulus: Torsion occurs along the vertical axis. It is partial (<180 
degrees) and recurrent. It is not associated with a diaphragmatic defect. The Borchardt triad is seen in gastric volvulus: • Sudden-onset severe upper abdominal pain • Recurrent retching with production of little vomitus • Inability to pass a nasogastric (NG) tube 440 
Sold by @itachibot Management involves reduction and uncoiling of the stomach through a transabdominal 
approach.

questions.question:
Question 28: A 40-year-old male presented to the OPD with complaints of abdominal pain, diarrhea, loss 
of appetite, and loss of weight. On examination, the patient had peripheral edema and ascites. 
Laboratory studies showed decreased serum albumin but normal serum levels of 
transaminases and gastrin. Upper GI endoscopy showed the following appearance of the 
stomach. Which of the following is true about the condition? 423 
Sold by @itachibot
questions.explanation:
The given clinical scenario and the image showing the presence of hypertrophied gastric mucosal 
folds are characteristic of Menetrier’s disease. Gastrectomy is the treatment of choice in severe 
cases of Menetrier's disease. Menetrier's disease is a premalignant condition. The disease seems to be caused by 
overexpression of transforming growth factor-alpha i.e., TGF-alpha (not TNF-alpha), which 
stimulates the EGFR pathway, resulting in increased proliferation of mucus cells/foveolar 
hyperplasia. This results in gross hypertrophy of the gastric mucosal folds, mucus production, and 
hypochlorhydria. The antrum is usually spared. There is a loss of albumin (up to 10 g/day), across the gastric mucosa leading to hypoproteinemia. 
Secondary symptoms include weight loss, diarrhea, and peripheral edema. Histologically, it is characterized by hyperplasia of foveolar mucous cells. The glands are cystically 
dilated and elongated with a corkscrew-like appearance as shown in the image below. Cetuximab, an EGFR inhibitory antibody, is now considered the first-line treatment for 
Menetrier's disease, leaving total gastrectomy for severe disease with persistent and substantial 
protein loss refractory to cetuximab. 441 
Sold by @itachibot Carcinoma Stomach
